facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 974 of 1968 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 974 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated December 22, 1967 and January 3, 1968 of Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 3369 W of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated December 22, 1967 and January 3, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 3369 W  of 1966.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Grover, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgement of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.-This is an appeal from a judgment of a learned single judge

facts.text: Agreement entered into between Government of India and Pakistan on September 10, 1958 called Indo-Pakistan Agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The facts may be shortly stated. On September 10, 1958, an agreement was entered into between the Government of India and Pakistan called the Indo-Pakistan Agreement.

facts.text: Item No. 3 of the agreement related to Berabari Union No. 12, a group of villages lying within territory of India.

anchor.surface_text: Item No. 3 of the agreement related to Berabari Union No. 12 which was a group of, villages lying within the territory of India.

facts.text: Berabari Union territory to be divided giving one half area to Pakistan, other half retained by India.

anchor.surface_text: This territory was to be so divided as to give one half area to Pakistan. The other half adjacent to India was to be retained by India.

facts.text: President of India made reference to Supreme Court under Art. 143(1) on Berubari Union.

anchor.surface_text: The President of India made a reference to this Court under Art. 143 1 , of the Constitution for its advisory opinion.

facts.text: Supreme Court advisory opinion delivered on March 14, 1960 in Re Berubari Union.

anchor.surface_text: The opinion was deliverted on March 14, 1960.  In Re The Berubari Union and Exchange of Enclaves Reference Under Article 143  1  of the Constitution

facts.text: Berubari Union No. 12 had area of 8.75 sq. miles and population of 10 to 12 thousand, in Jalpaiguri district.

anchor.surface_text: As mentioned in the advisory opinion Berubari Union No. 12 had an area of 8-75 Sq. Miles and a, population of 10 to 12 thousand residents. It was situated in the district, of Jalpaiguri.

facts.text: Parliament enacted Constitution Ninth Amendment Act 1960 on December 28, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the opinion delivered by this Court the Parliament enacted C. As. 2634/69 63/70 decided on 23-2-70.  2  1971 3 S.C.R. 483.  3  1960 3 S. C. R. 250. the Constitution  Ninth Amendment  Act 1960 on December 28, 1960.

facts.text: Inhabitants of Berubari Union filed petition under Art. 226 challenging partition.

anchor.surface_text: Some of the, inhabitants of the Berubari Union filed a petition under Article 226 of the Constitution challenging its proposed partition

facts.text: Writ petition dismissed, appeal to Supreme Court disposed on August 11, 1965 in Ram Kishore Sen v. Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: The Writ petition was dismissed and an appeal was brought to this Court which was disposed of on August 11, 1965.  Ram Kishore Sen Others v. Union of India Ors.  1 .

facts.text: Respondents filed petition under Art. 226 on June 11, 1965 challenging demarcation on ground of citizenship and property without compensation.

anchor.surface_text: On June 11, 1965, the respondents filed another petition under Article 226 of the Constitution before the High Court challenging the validity of the proposed demarcation principally on the ground right of citizenship

facts.text: D. Basu J. of Calcutta High Court delivered judgment directing rule nisi on ground No. 3.

anchor.surface_text: D. Basu J. called for an affidavit in opposition and after hearing lengthy arguments delivered an elaborate judgment I.R. 1967 Cal. 216  directing the issue of rule nisi limited to ground No. 3 of the writ petition.

facts.text: Respondent Dhanoswar Roy had 2 acres 64 decimals of khas land in the area.

anchor.surface_text: According to the allegation in the writ petition respondent Dhanoswar Roy had 2 acres 64 decimals of khas land in the area in question.

facts.text: Respondents had household property, ancestral homes and cultivated lands in Berubari Union No. 12.

anchor.surface_text: It was also claimed that the respondents had their household property, ancestral homes and cultivated lands in the Berubari Union No. 12.

facts.text: High Court held that cession involves compulsory acquisition under Art. 31(2) requiring compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The cession of the disputed properties sought to be implemented by the impugned demarcation involved companypulsory acquisition of those properties by the Union of India within the meaning of Art. 31 2

facts.text: Supreme Court holds no compulsory acquisition under Art. 31(2) in cession to Pakistan.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment numberquestion of acquisition within Art. 31 2  is involved in the present case and even though a good deal of hardship may result to the respondents

facts.text: Appeal allowed, no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Single judge granted certificate under Art. 132(1) despite Letters Patent appeal available.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that on an oral prayer made to him he granted a certificate under Art. 132 1  even though under the Letters Patent of the High Court an appeal lay to a division bench of that companyrt.

facts.text: Berubari Union implementation requires physical division and demarcation.

anchor.surface_text: In order to implement the provisions of the above Act a physical division of the Berubari Union in accordance with the agreement and demarcation of the portion that was to go to Pakistan was necessary.

facts.text: Supreme Court in Berubari opinion stated implementation requires amendment under Art. 368.

anchor.surface_text: This Court expressed the view that since the agreement between India and Pakistan a mounted to cession of a part of the territory of India in favour of Pakistan its implementation would naturally involve the alteration

The Judgement of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.-This is an appeal from a judgment of a learned single judge of the Calcutta High Court who granted a certificate under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution. It involves primarily the question whether the cession of a territory by India as a result of a treaty with Pakistan would be companypulsory acquisition of the property companyrised in that territory by the Union of India and would, therefore, attract the provisions of Art. 31 of our Constitution.

certificate under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution. It involves primarily the question whether the cession of a territory by India as a result of a treaty with Pakistan would be companypulsory acquisition of the property companyrised in that territory by the Union of India and would, therefore, attract the provisions of Art. 31 of our Constitution. At the outset it may be mentioned with reference to a preli- minary objection which has been raised by the respondents that the judgment under appeal was delivered by the learned single Judge in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Stress has been laid on the true import of cession. According to all authorities on International Law cession is the transfer of sovereignty over the State territory by the owner State to another State 1 . Under the International Law two of the essential attributes of sovereignty are the power to ac- quire foreign territory as well as the power to cede national territory in favour of foreign State 2   supra at p. 281 .

concepts.interpretation: Cession transfers sovereignty, not private property rights, which continue unless abrogated by new sovereign; no acquisition by ceding state.

issues.text: whether the cession of a territory by India as a result of a treaty with Pakistan would be compulsory acquisition of the property comprised in that territory by the Union of India and would, therefore, attract the provisions of Art. 31 of our Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It involves primarily the question whether the cession of a territory by India as a result of a treaty with Pakistan would be compulsory acquisition of the property comprised in that territory by the Union of India and would, therefore, attract the provisions of Art. 31 of our Constitution.

issues.text: whether a single judge of the High Court can grant a certificate under Art. 132(1) for appeal to the Supreme Court when an appeal lies to a division bench under the Letters Patent

anchor.surface_text: At the outset it may be mentioned with reference to a preliminary objection which has been raised by the respondents that the judgment under appeal was delivered by the learned single Judge in a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution and it appears that on an oral prayer made to him he granted a certificate under Art. 132 1 even though under the Letters Patent of the High Court an appeal lay to a division bench of that court.

issues.text: whether any Act of the State is involved in the transfer of Berubari Union No. 12 to Pakistan and as such the petitioners are entitled to compensation in terms of Art. 31(2) of the Constitution inasmuch as the operation of transfer involves deprivation of their right to property for which no provision has been made in the Constitution 9th Amendment Act, 1960

anchor.surface_text: This ground was For that no Act of the State is involved in the transfer of Berubari Union No. 12 to Pakistan and as such your petitioners are entitled to compensation in terms of Art. 31 2 of the Constitution inasmuch as the operation of transfer involves deprivation of their right to property for which no provision has been made in the Constitution 9th Amendment Act, 1960.

issues.text: whether compensation under Article 31(2) of the Constitution was to be provided for the respondents before the demarcation in implementation of the Constitution Ninth Amendment Act took place

anchor.surface_text: The constitutional question formulated by the learned judge was whether compensation under Article 31 2 of the Constitution was to be provided for the respondents before the demarcation in implementation of the Constitution Ninth Amendment Act took place.

issues.text: whether the cession of the disputed properties involves compulsory acquisition of those properties by the Union of India within the meaning of Art. 31(2)

issues.text: whether the effect of the Constitution Ninth Amendment Act 1960 by which part of the Berubari Union No. 12 shall be ceded to Pakistan can be regarded as a transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property to the State within the meaning of Art. 12 and clause 2A of Art. 31

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the Constitution Ninth Amendment Act 1960 by which part of the Berubari Union No. 12 shall be ceded to Pakistan can by no stretch of reasoning be regarded as a transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property of the respondents to the State within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: the practice of a single Judge deciding the case and giving a certificate under Art. 132(1) for appeal to this Court, although technically correct, was an improper practice

anchor.surface_text: This Court has said on an earlier occasion in clear and unequivocal terms that the practice of a single Judge deciding the case and giving a certificate under Art. 132 1  for appeal to this Court, al- though technically companyrect, was an improper practice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restates prior Supreme Court precedents criticizing the practice and emphasizing right to High Court division bench appeal under Letters Patent should not be bypassed

holdings.text: Even though the present case may be of an exceptional kind [...] we have been deprived of the benefit of the judgment of a larger bench of the High Court [...] The Court proceeds to merits

anchor.surface_text: Even though the present case may be of an exceptional kind we have been deprived of the benefit of the judgment of a larger bench of the High Court on points which are of substantial importance. Presumably a number of matters which had numberbearing on the real questions to be determined and which have been dealt with by the learned single judge would have been either satisfactorily disposed of or would number have been the subject matter of discussion by the companyrt, being irrelevant and unnecessary, if the decision had been given by a larger Bench.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges exceptional nature but notes loss of larger bench view; elects to decide on merits without dismissing appeal

holdings.text: Cession indisputably involves transference of sovereignty from one sovereign State to another. There is no transference of ownership or right to possession in the properties of the inhabitants of the territory ceded to the ceding State itself

anchor.surface_text: Cession indisputably involves transference of sovereignty from one sovereign State to another. There is numbertransference of ownership or right to possession in the properties of the inhabitants of the territory ceded to the ceding State itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies international law authorities defining cession as sovereignty transfer, distinguishing from property ownership transfer to ceding state

holdings.text: The effect of the Constitution Ninth Amendment Act 1960 by which part of the Berubari Union No. 12 shall be ceded to Pakistan can by no stretch of reasoning be regarded as a transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property of the respondents to the State within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the Constitution  Ninth Amendment  Act 1960 by which part of the Berubari Union No. 12 shall be ceded to Pakistan can by numberstretch of reasoning be regarded as a transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property of the respondents to the State within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ninth Amendment cedes territory to Pakistan (not a 'State' under Art.12); no ownership/possession transfer to Union of India as required by Art.31(2A)

holdings.text: The view of the High Court that the cession of the said territory involves transfer of the ownership and other private property rights to Pakistan through the Union of India which was outside clause 2A of Article 31 and was covered by clause 2 of that Article is to say the least wholly untenable and cannot be sustained

anchor.surface_text: The view of the High Court that the cession of the said territory involves transfer of the ownership and other private property rights to Pakistan through the Union of India which was outside clause 2A  of Article 31 and was companyred by clause  2  of that Article is to say the least wholly untenable and cannot be sustained.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in finding acquisition under Art.31(2) bypassing 2A; correct law requires property transfer to Indian 'State', not sovereignty to foreign state

holdings.text: no question of acquisition within Art. 31(2) is involved in the present case and even though a good deal of hardship may result to the respondents owing to the change of sovereignty they cannot claim compensation for the simple reason that there has been no transfer of the ownership of their property to the State namely the Union of India which would attract the applicability of Art. 31(2)

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment numberquestion of acquisition within Art. 31 2  is involved in the present case and even though a good deal of hardship may result to the respondents owing to the change of sovereignty they cannot claim companypensation for the simple reason that there has been numbertransfer of the ownership of their property to the State namely the Union of India which would attract the applicability of Art. 31 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: No property acquisition by Union despite hardship from sovereignty change; relies on Art.31(2A) requiring ownership transfer to Art.12 'State', prior precedents on acquisition definition, intl law on cession

holdings.text: Even on the assumption that the respondents will not be entitled to enforce their private rights in the municipal courts of Pakistan unless they are recognised by the new sovereign it is incomprehensible how such a prospect or possibility can attract the applicability of Art. 31(2) of our Constitution so as to entitle the respondents to compensation as provided thereby

anchor.surface_text: Even on the assumption that the respondents will number be entitled to enforce their private rights in the municipal companyrts of Pakistan unless they are recognised by the new sovereign it is incomprehensible how such a prospect or possibility can attract the applicability of Art. 31 2  of our Constitution so as to entitle the respondens to companypensation as provided thereby.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Loss of enforceability in Pakistan courts (even assumed) does not trigger Indian constitutional acquisition/compensation by Union of India

holdings.text: The Constitution Ninth Amendment Act having been enacted in accordance with the Advisory opinion of this Court there can be no impediment in the way of ceding part of Berubari Union No. 12 pursuant to the Indo-Pakistan Treaty 1958

anchor.surface_text: The Constitution  Ninth Amendment  Act having been enacted in accordance with the Advisory opinion of this companyrt 1  there can be numberimpediment in the way of ceding part of Berubari Union No. 12 pursuant to the Indo- Pakistan Treaty 1958.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act complies with prior advisory opinion under Art.143(1); no further constitutional bar to implementation absent Art.31(2) violation

anchor.surface_text: Even though the present case may be of an exceptional kind we have been deprived of the benefit of the judgment of a larger bench of the High Court on points which are of substantial importance. Presumably a number of matters which had numberbearing on the real questions to be determined and which have been dealt with by the learned single judge would have been either satisfactorily disposed of or would number have been the subject matter of discussion by the companyrt, being irrelevant and unnecessary, if the decision had been given by a larger Bench.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the Constitution  Ninth Amendment  Act 1960 by which part of the Berubari Union No. 12 shall be ceded to Pakistan can by numberstretch of reasoning be regarded as a transfer of the ownership or right to possession of any property of the respondents to the State within the meaning of Art. 12 of the Constitution.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.

The view of the High Court that the cession of the said territory involves transfer of the ownership and other private property rights to Pakistan through the Union of India which was outside clause 2A  of Article 31 and was companyred by clause  2  of that Article is to say the least wholly untenable and cannot be sustained.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 states 'no question of acquisition within Art. 31(2) is involved', directly addressing and negating the question in issue i1 about whether cession constitutes compulsory acquisition.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment numberquestion of acquisition within Art. 31 2  is involved in the present case and even though a good deal of hardship may result to the respondents owing to the change of sovereignty they cannot claim companypensation for the simple reason that there has been numbertransfer of the ownership of their property to the State namely the Union of India which would attract the applicability of Art. 31 2 .
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.

Even on the assumption that the respondents will number be entitled to enforce their private rights in the municipal companyrts of Pakistan unless they are recognised by the new sovereign it is incomprehensible how such a prospect or possibility can attract the applicability of Art. 31 2  of our Constitution so as to entitle the respondens to companypensation as provided thereby.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.

The Constitution  Ninth Amendment  Act having been enacted in accordance with the Advisory opinion of this companyrt 1  there can be numberimpediment in the way of ceding part of Berubari Union No. 12 pursuant to the Indo- Pakistan Treaty 1958.
The appeal, therefore, succeeds and it is hereby allowed. In view of the nature of the points decided there will be numberorder as to companyts.
